source.name: City of Atlanta Department of Public Works
source.notes: Based on official City of Atlanta recycling guidelines. Weekly blue cart collection. 'Tanglers' (hoses, cords, clothing, rope) explicitly banned from recycling.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: Atlanta accepts all rigid plastic bottles
No need to remove labels
Cart must be out by 7 AM on collection day
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still inside
Don't crush; leave as-is with cap on

materials.name: Milk jugs
notes: HDPE plastic jugs are highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't leave milk residue inside

materials.name: Detergent and cleaning bottles
notes: Must be empty; residual product is OK after rinsing
Includes laundry, dish, and household cleaner bottles
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles that still have product in them
Don't include trigger sprayer bottles with metal springs (remove sprayer head)

materials.name: Shampoo and personal care bottles
notes: Includes shampoo, conditioner, body wash, and lotion bottles
commonMistakes: Don't include tubes (toothpaste, lotion tubes) — those go in trash

materials.name: Plastic food tubs and containers
notes: Atlanta accepts rigid plastic food tubs and containers
Must be free of food residue
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with food still in them
Don't include thin plastic film lids — peel off and trash

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
notes: Atlanta accepts all colors: clear, green, and brown glass
Only food and beverage glass containers are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics
Don't include broken glass — wrap carefully and place in trash
Don't include drinking glasses, Pyrex, or crystal

materials.name: Aluminum cans
notes: Labels can stay on
Do not crush
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with liquid still in them
Don't include aluminum foil (see separate entry)

materials.name: Steel and tin food cans
notes: Includes all steel and tin food cans
A magnet will stick to steel/tin cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Don't include sharp lids loose — push lid inside can

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Only empty aerosol cans are accepted
Non-empty aerosol cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if can still has pressure or product
Don't puncture the can

materials.name: Office paper and mail
instructions: Place loose in blue recycling cart
No need to remove staples or window envelopes
notes: Must be clean and dry
Do not shred — shredded paper is not accepted curbside
commonMistakes: Don't include wet or food-soiled paper
Don't bag paper in plastic bags
Don't include shredded paper

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place loose in blue recycling cart
Inserts and circulars can stay in
notes: Must be dry
Do not bundle with string or rubber bands
commonMistakes: Don't include newspapers soaked with water or other liquids

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Remove plastic wrapping if any (trash the wrapping)
notes: Glossy paper is accepted in Atlanta recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic wrapping — trash it separately

materials.name: Flattened cardboard
instructions: Remove all packing materials (styrofoam, bubble wrap, air pillows)
Cut to fit inside blue recycling cart
notes: Must be clean and dry
Must fit inside the cart — do not leave cardboard beside the cart
commonMistakes: Don't include wet or food-soiled cardboard
Don't leave unflattened boxes
Remove all tape is not required, but remove packing materials

materials.name: Paperboard boxes
instructions: Remove plastic liners or bags (trash those)
notes: Thin paperboard (like cereal boxes) is accepted
Must be clean and free of food residue
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the plastic liner bag
Don't include heavily food-soiled paperboard

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Ball up small pieces into a ball at least 2 inches wide
notes: Must be clean — heavily soiled foil goes in trash
Foil pans and pie tins are also accepted if clean
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food or grease
Small scraps get lost — ball them together

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in blue recycling cart
notes: Clean paper bags are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle paper bags soiled with food or grease

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
notes: Gable-top and aseptic cartons are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cartons with liquid still inside

materials.name: Books
instructions: If damaged, place in blue recycling cart
Hardcovers: remove thick covers with glossy laminate if possible (trash those)
notes: Donating is always preferred over recycling
Atlanta-Fulton Public Library accepts book donations
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the trash

materials.name: Paper egg cartons
notes: Only paper/cardboard egg cartons — not styrofoam
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons — those go in trash

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Place loose metal lids inside a steel can and crimp the opening to contain them
notes: Small loose lids can fall through sorting screens
Containing them inside a can helps them get recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put tiny loose metal caps directly in the bin without containing them

materials.name: Tanglers (hoses, cords, clothing, rope)
instructions: Place in trash — NEVER in the blue recycling cart
For clothing in good condition, donate instead
notes: Tanglers wrap around recycling sorting equipment and shut down the facility
This is one of Atlanta's most emphasized recycling contamination issues
The Keep Atlanta Beautiful Commission specifically warns about tanglers
commonMistakes: Never put hoses, cords, rope, clothing, or string lights in recycling
Even small lengths of rope or cord can cause equipment jams

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling cart
Take clean, dry bags to grocery store drop-off bins
notes: Plastic bags and film jam Atlanta's recycling equipment
Most Kroger and Publix stores in Atlanta accept bags for recycling
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Never put film plastic in the blue cart

materials.name: Styrofoam and foam
instructions: Not accepted in Atlanta curbside recycling
Take large amounts of clean EPS foam to CHaRM for recycling
notes: Styrofoam contaminates the recycling stream
CHaRM (Center for Hard to Recycle Materials) accepts clean expanded polystyrene
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Food waste and scraps
instructions: Atlanta does NOT offer curbside composting
notes: No curbside composting program is available in Atlanta
Consider backyard composting or community composting programs
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the blue recycling cart
Don't pour liquids into the recycling cart

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: Consider backyard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: Consider backyard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put vegetable scraps in recycling

materials.name: Meat and bones
notes: Atlanta does not have curbside composting
Never compost meat at home — it attracts pests
commonMistakes: Don't put meat or bones in recycling

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: No curbside composting in Atlanta
commonMistakes: Rinse the container before placing it in the blue cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Atlanta does not have curbside composting
notes: Consider backyard composting for coffee grounds and paper filters
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Window glass, mirrors, and ceramics
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
notes: These types of glass have different melting points than bottle glass and contaminate recycling
Ceramics also contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put window glass, mirrors, or ceramics in the blue recycling cart
Don't confuse with food/beverage glass containers (which are recyclable)

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to CHaRM or Home Depot/Lowe's for recycling
Incandescent: wrap and place in trash
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury and require special handling
Atlanta's CHaRM facility accepts all types of light bulbs
Atlanta explicitly bans light bulbs from the blue recycling cart
commonMistakes: Don't put any light bulbs in the blue recycling cart
Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in regular trash

materials.name: Paper plates and napkins
instructions: Not recyclable when soiled with food
notes: Food-contaminated paper products are not accepted in Atlanta recycling
No curbside composting available
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Takeout containers
instructions: Foam takeout containers are never recyclable in Atlanta
notes: Even non-foam takeout containers are typically too food-soiled for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put takeout containers in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic utensils and straws
notes: Too small and lightweight to be sorted at the recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic utensils in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Plastic-lined paper cups are not recyclable in Atlanta
notes: The inner plastic lining prevents recycling
Plastic lids also go in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: If heavily soiled with grease: place in trash
If clean (top half): tear off clean portion and recycle it
notes: Grease-soaked cardboard contaminates paper recycling
No curbside composting available in Atlanta for greasy paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy cardboard in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Candy and snack wrappers
instructions: Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
notes: Wrappers appear metallic but are multi-layer bonded plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Chip bags and snack bags
instructions: Metallized film is not recyclable in Atlanta
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic — cannot be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Bubble wrap and air pillows
instructions: Or take plastic film to grocery store drop-off bins
notes: Plastic film and bubble wrap are not accepted in Atlanta curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Thermal paper contains BPA and contaminates paper recycling
notes: Most modern receipts use thermal printing
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Not recyclable due to wax/silicone coating
notes: No curbside composting available in Atlanta
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Food-soiled paper is not recyclable in Atlanta
notes: Atlanta has no curbside composting for food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Atlanta does NOT accept shredded paper in curbside recycling
notes: Shredded paper clogs recycling equipment and is too small to sort
Consider composting at home
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in the blue recycling cart
Don't bag shredded paper and put it in recycling

materials.name: Styrofoam egg cartons
instructions: Styrofoam is not recyclable curbside in Atlanta
notes: Only paper/cardboard egg cartons are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam egg cartons in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Most wrapping paper goes in trash due to glitter, foil, or plastic lamination
Plain paper wrapping (no glitter/foil/coating): can be recycled
notes: Do the scrunch test: if it stays scrunched in a ball, it may be recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Mixed plastic — not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Pet waste
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria
Not compostable
commonMistakes: Never compost pet waste
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Makeup and cosmetics containers
instructions: Most containers go in trash due to small size and mixed materials
Check brand take-back programs (e.g., MAC, Kiehl's)
notes: Small items fall through sorting screens at recycling facilities
Nail polish is considered hazardous
commonMistakes: Nail polish: take to CHaRM or household hazardous waste

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to CHaRM (Center for Hard to Recycle Materials)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries cause fires in recycling trucks and landfills
CHaRM accepts all battery types for Atlanta residents
Some Home Depot and Lowe's locations also accept rechargeable batteries
commonMistakes: Never throw batteries in trash or recycling
Tape the terminals of lithium batteries to prevent fires

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Take to CHaRM (Center for Hard to Recycle Materials)
Best Buy also accepts many electronics for free recycling
notes: Georgia law restricts electronics in regular trash
CHaRM is free for City of Atlanta residents
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling cart
Always wipe personal data first

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to CHaRM (Center for Hard to Recycle Materials)
Latex paint: can also dry out with kitty litter and trash the solid
Oil-based paint: must go to hazardous waste
notes: CHaRM accepts all types of paint from Atlanta residents
Never pour paint down the drain or into storm drains
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint cans in trash

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to CHaRM or AutoZone/O'Reilly in Atlanta
Collect in a sealed container for transport
notes: Most auto parts stores accept used oil for free
Never pour down drains or into storm drains
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't mix different automotive fluids together

materials.name: Cleaning products and household chemicals
instructions: Take to CHaRM (Center for Hard to Recycle Materials)
Empty containers that held non-hazardous cleaners: rinse and recycle if rigid plastic bottle
notes: Never mix chemicals together
CHaRM accepts household hazardous waste from Atlanta residents
commonMistakes: Don't pour chemicals down drains
Don't put partially full containers in trash

materials.name: Propane tanks and cylinders
instructions: Take to CHaRM — never put in trash or recycling
Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks
notes: Atlanta explicitly lists propane as banned from recycling
CHaRM accepts propane tanks
commonMistakes: Never puncture or put in trash or recycling

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to CHaRM or Home Depot/Lowe's
Transport in original box or wrap securely
notes: Contains mercury — requires special handling
CHaRM accepts fluorescent tubes for Atlanta residents
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling
Don't break them — mercury vapor is hazardous

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Take to CHaRM or check with your pharmacy
notes: Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
Fulton County Health Department may also accept sharps
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in trash or recycling

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to drug take-back locations in Atlanta
CVS and Walgreens in Atlanta participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off available: mix with coffee grounds, seal in bag, and trash
notes: Atlanta Police holds periodic drug take-back events
CHaRM also accepts medications
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local Atlanta thrift stores
Even worn-out textiles can be taken to CHaRM or textile recycling bins
Do NOT put in blue recycling cart — clothing is a 'tangler'
notes: Atlanta specifically classifies clothing as a 'tangler' that damages recycling equipment
Donate wearable items; recycle worn-out textiles at CHaRM
Many locations throughout Atlanta accept textile donations
commonMistakes: Never put clothing in the blue recycling cart
Even torn or stained textiles can be recycled — don't trash them

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer or CHaRM
Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Illegal to dump tires in Georgia
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in trash

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
notes: Grease causes sewer blockages
CHaRM accepts used cooking oil from Atlanta residents
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup through Atlanta 311
notes: Atlanta offers bulk item pickup by request through 311
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Large and bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulk pickup through Atlanta 311: call (404) 330-6333
Place at curb on scheduled day
Or donate usable items to local Atlanta thrift stores
notes: Atlanta offers scheduled bulk pickups through the Department of Public Works
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling a pickup

materials.name: Ink and toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
notes: Some stores give rewards credit for cartridge returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Smartphone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe data first
Trade in at carrier stores or Apple/Samsung stores in Atlanta
Take to Best Buy or CHaRM for free recycling
notes: Georgia law restricts electronics in trash
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in trash or recycling

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in separate yard waste bags or bundles on collection day
Branches must be cut to 4 feet or less and bundled
Contact Atlanta DPW at (404) 330-6333 for yard waste schedule
notes: Atlanta collects yard waste separately from regular trash
Do not use plastic bags — use paper bags or leave loose in unlidded containers
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in the blue recycling cart
Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags

materials.name: Chargers, cables, and wires
instructions: Take to Best Buy or CHaRM — do NOT put in blue recycling cart
Cables are classified as 'tanglers' in Atlanta
notes: Cables and cords tangle in recycling machinery and cause shutdowns
commonMistakes: Never put cables or chargers in curbside recycling

recycle: Office paper, mail, newspapers, magazines, and catalogs
Paperboard (cereal boxes, tissue boxes, shoe boxes)
Plastic bottles and containers (beverage, milk jugs, detergent, shampoo, food tubs)
Glass bottles and jars (clear, green, and brown)
trash: All food waste and scraps (no curbside composting)

recycle: Plastic bags, film, and shrink wrap
Tanglers (hoses, cords, clothing, rope, string lights)
Window glass, mirrors, light bulbs, ceramics

tips: Weekly collection — place blue cart at curb by 7 AM on collection day
Keep cart at least 3 feet from trash cart and other obstacles
All recyclables must be empty, clean, and dry
No plastic bags — place items loose in the blue cart
Tanglers (hoses, cords, clothing, rope) damage sorting equipment — keep them out
Glass of all colors (clear, green, brown) is accepted curbside
Atlanta has NO curbside composting — food waste goes in trash
Take hard-to-recycle items to CHaRM at 1110 Hill St SE
Call (404) 330-6333 for questions or to schedule bulk pickup
Keep Atlanta Beautiful Commission manages the recycling program

locations.name: CHaRM — Center for Hard to Recycle Materials
locations.notes: Operated by LiveThrive. Free for City of Atlanta residents with valid ID. Accepts a wide range of hard-to-recycle materials.

locations.name: Atlanta Department of Public Works
locations.address: 55 Trinity Ave SW, Suite 4700, Atlanta, GA 30303
locations.notes: Call for curbside recycling questions, bulk pickups, or to report missed collections.

locations.name: Keep Atlanta Beautiful Commission
locations.notes: Manages Atlanta's recycling and litter reduction programs. Educational resources for residents and businesses.
